messageBody:
Kamal,

I'm glad you found the paper helpful. It would be helpful to have objective
measures for the three factors I found. In my own practice I rely on
intuition and experience to evaluate them.

Thinking aloud:
* Cost--you can certainly measure the runtime of tests, the number of
lines of code required to set up the test, and the frequency with which the
test needs attention. These are all a posteriori measures, though. I'm not
sure how you would estimate them beforehand with any precision.
* Stability--again, this is possible to measure after the fact, but I
don't see how to estimate it objectively. Techniques like partial validation
are helpful with interfaces that are likely to be unstable, like XML, PDF,
or HTML.
* Reliability--and again, you could measure this after the fact by, for
example, tracing the execution of the code invoked by a test and counting
the number of conditionals and polymorphic messages.

I've given up on trying to objective about evaluating these factors. My gut
gives me reasonable feedback in my daily work. If someone comes up with
effective prediction, I'd like to hear about it, though.

Regards,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

Subject: [junit] Where to test?

All,

Last week on succeeding days I encountered two situations, one where
system-level tests were valuable and unit tests would have been useless and
one where the reverse was true. Since simply the level of the tests is not
sufficient to decide where to test, I thought a bit more about how I should
decide where to test. I came to three criteria:
* The cost of writing and running the test
* The stability of the interface the test is, errr..., testing
* The reliability of the code satisfying the test

I wrote this up in a little paper:
www.threeriversinst itute.org/ WhereToTest. html. Comments welcome.

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
